gnnwr.datasets module

gnnwr.datasets.BasicDistance(x, y)

Parameters:

  • x – Input point coordinate data

  • y – Input target point coordinate data

Returns:

distance matrix

gnnwr.datasets.Manhattan_distance(x, y)

Calculate the Manhattan distance between two points

Parameters:

  • x – Input point coordinate data

  • y – Input target point coordinate data

Returns:

distance matrix

class gnnwr.datasets.baseDataset(data=None, x_column=None, y_column=None, id_column=None, is_need_STNN=False)

Bases: Dataset

baseDataset is the base class of dataset, which is used to store the data and other information. it also provides the function of data scaling, data saving and data loading.

Parameters:

  • data – DataSets with x_column and y_column

  • x_column – independent variables column name

  • y_column – dependent variables column name

  • is_need_STNN – whether to use STNN

getScaledDataframe()

get the scaled dataframe

read(dirname)

read the dataset by the directory

Parameters:

dirname – read directory

rescale(x, y)
Parameters:

  • x – Input independent variable data

  • y – Input dependent variable data

Returns:

rescaled x and y

save(dirname)

save the dataset

Parameters:

dirname – save directory

scale(scale_fn=None, scale_params=None)

scale the data by MinMaxScaler or StandardScaler

Parameters:

  • scale_fn – scale function

  • scale_params – scale parameters like MinMaxScaler or StandardScaler

scale2(scale_fn, scale_params)

scale the data with the scale function and scale parameters

Parameters:

  • scale_fn – scale function

  • scale_params – scale parameters like max and min

gnnwr.datasets.init_dataset(data, test_ratio, valid_ratio, x_column, y_column, spatial_column=None, temp_column=None, id_column=None, sample_seed=100, process_fn='minmax_scale', batch_size=32, shuffle=True, use_class=<class 'gnnwr.datasets.baseDataset'>, spatial_fun=<function BasicDistance>, temporal_fun=<function Manhattan_distance>, max_val_size=-1, max_test_size=-1, from_for_cv=0, is_need_STNN=False, Reference=None, simple_distance=True)

Initialize the dataset and return the training set, validation set and test set for the model

Parameters:

  • data – dataset

  • test_ratio – test data ratio

  • valid_ratio – valid data ratio

  • x_column – input attribute column name

  • y_column – output attribute column name

  • spatial_column – spatial attribute column name

  • temp_column – temporal attribute column name

  • sample_seed – random seed

  • process_fn – data pre-process function

  • batch_size – batch size

  • max_val_size – max valid data size in one injection

  • max_test_size – max test data size in one injection

  • shuffle – shuffle data

  • use_class – dataset class

  • spatial_fun – spatial distance calculate function

  • temporal_fun – temporal distance calculate function

  • from_for_cv – the start index of the data for cross validation

  • is_need_STNN – whether to use STNN

  • Reference – reference points to calculate the distance

  • simple_distance – whether to use simple distance function to calculate the distance

Returns:

train dataset, valid dataset, test dataset

gnnwr.datasets.init_dataset_cv(data, test_ratio, k_fold, x_column, y_column, spatial_column=None, temp_column=None, id_column=None, sample_seed=100, process_fn='minmax_scale', batch_size=32, shuffle=True, use_class=<class 'gnnwr.datasets.baseDataset'>, spatial_fun=<function BasicDistance>, temporal_fun=<function Manhattan_distance>, max_val_size=-1, max_test_size=-1, is_need_STNN=False, Reference=None, simple_distance=True)

initialize dataset for cross validation

Parameters:

  • data – input data

  • test_ratio – test set ratio

  • k_fold – k of k-fold

  • x_column – attribute column name

  • y_column – label column name

  • spatial_column – spatial distance column name

  • temp_column – temporal distance column name

  • sample_seed – random seed

  • process_fn – data process function

  • batch_size – batch size

  • shuffle – shuffle or not

  • use_class – dataset class

  • spatial_fun – spatial distance calculate function

  • temporal_fun – temporal distance calculate function

  • max_val_size – validation set size

  • max_test_size – test set size

Returns:

cv_data_set, test_dataset

gnnwr.datasets.init_predict_dataset(data, train_dataset, x_column, spatial_column=None, temp_column=None, process_fn='minmax_scale', scale_sync=True, use_class=<class 'gnnwr.datasets.predictDataset'>, spatial_fun=<function BasicDistance>, temporal_fun=<function Manhattan_distance>, max_size=-1, is_need_STNN=False)

  • scale_sync – scale sync or not

  • max_size – max size of predict dataset

gnnwr.models module

class gnnwr.models.GNNWR(train_dataset, valid_dataset, test_dataset, dense_layers=None, start_lr: float = 0.1, optimizer='Adagrad', drop_out=0.2, batch_norm=True, activate_func=PReLU(num_parameters=1), model_name='GNNWR_20230920-000000', model_save_path='../gnnwr_models', write_path='../gnnwr_runs/20230920-161710', use_gpu: bool = True, use_ols: bool = True, log_path='../gnnwr_logs/', log_file_name='gnnwr20230920-161710.log', log_level=20, optimizer_params=None)

Bases: object

GNNWR is a model used to regress the output of a system with the input of the system. It is a combination of SWNN and STNN.

Parameters:

  • train_dataset – train dataset

  • valid_dataset – valid dataset

  • test_dataset – test dataset

  • dense_layers – structure of layers (can be None, which means the default structure will be used)

  • start_lr – initial learning rate

  • optimizer – optimizer types(SGD, Adam, RMSprop, Adagrad)

  • drop_out – drop_out ratio

  • batch_norm – batch normalization

  • activate_func – activate function , default: PRelu(0.4)

  • model_name – name of model

  • model_save_path – path to save model

  • write_path – path to save tensorboard logs

  • use_gpu – whether to use gpu

  • use_ols – whether to use OLS

  • log_path – path to save log

  • log_file_name – name of log file

  • log_level – log level

  • optimizer_params – parameters of optimizer and learning rate scheduler

add_graph()

add graph to tensorboard

getLoss()

get network’s loss

init_optimizer(optimizer, optimizer_params=None)

Initialize the optimizer and set the learning rate scheduler

Parameters:

  • optimizer – optimizer type name

  • optimizer_params – parameters of optimizer and learning rate scheduler

load_model(path, use_dict=False)

load model from the path

Parameters:

  • path – the path of the model

  • use_dict – whether use dict to load the model

predict(dataset)

predict the result of the dataset

Parameters:

dataset – Input dataset

reg_result(filename, model_path=None, use_dict=False)

save the result of the model, including the weight, the result of dataset

Parameters:

  • filename – the path of the result

  • model_path – the path of the model

  • use_dict – whether use dict to load the model

result(path=None, use_dict=False)

print the result of the model, including the model structure, optimizer,the result of test dataset

Parameters:

  • path – the path of the model

  • use_dict – whether use dict to load the model

run(max_epoch=1, early_stop=- 1, print_frequency=50, show_detailed_info=True)

train and validate the model

Parameters:

  • max_epoch – max epoch of training

  • early_stop – early stop epoch

  • print_frequency – print frequency

  • show_detailed_info – whether to show detailed information

class gnnwr.models.GTNNWR(train_dataset, valid_dataset, test_dataset, dense_layers=None, start_lr: float = 0.1, optimizer='Adam', drop_out=0.2, batch_norm=True, activate_func=PReLU(num_parameters=1), model_name='GTNNWR_20230920-161710', model_save_path='../gtnnwr_models', write_path='../gtnnwr_runs/20230920-161710', use_gpu: bool = True, use_ols: bool = True, log_path: str = '../gtnnwr_logs/', log_file_name: str = 'gtnnwr20230920-161710.log', log_level: int = 20, optimizer_params=None, STPNN_outsize=1, STNN_SPNN_params=None)

Bases: GNNWR

GTNNWR model is a model based on GNNWR and STPNN, which is a model that can be used to solve the problem of spatial-temporal non-stationarity.

Parameters:

  • train_dataset – the dataset of training

  • valid_dataset – the dataset of validation

  • test_dataset – the dataset of testing

  • dense_layers – the dense layers of the model

  • start_lr – the start learning rate of the model

  • optimizer – the optimizer of the model

  • drop_out – the drop out rate of the model

  • batch_norm – whether use batch normalization

  • activate_func – the activate function of the model (default: nn.PReLU(init=0.4))

  • model_name – the name of the model

  • model_save_path – the path of the model

  • write_path – the path of the log

  • use_gpu – whether use gpu

  • use_ols – whether use ols

  • log_path – the path of the log

  • log_file_name – the name of the log

  • log_level – the level of the log

  • optimizer_params – the params of the optimizer and the scheduler

  • STPNN_outsize – the output size of the STPNN

  • STNN_SPNN_params – the params of the STNN and SPNN

gnnwr.networks module

class gnnwr.networks.STNN_SPNN(STNN_insize: int, STNN_outsize, SPNN_insize: int, SPNN_outsize, activate_func=ReLU())

Bases: Module

STNN_SPNN is a neural network with dense layers, which is used to calculate the spatial proximity of two nodes and temporal proximity of two nodes at the same time.

Parameters:

  • STNN_insize – input size of STNN

  • STNN_outsize – output size of STNN

  • SPNN_insize – input size of SPNN

  • SPNN_outsize – output size of SPNN

  • activate_func – activate function

forward(input1)

Defines the computation performed at every call.

Should be overridden by all subclasses.

Note

Although the recipe for forward pass needs to be defined within this function, one should call the Module instance afterwards instead of this since the former takes care of running the registered hooks while the latter silently ignores them.

class gnnwr.networks.STPNN(dense_layer, insize, outsize, drop_out=0.2, activate_func=ReLU(), batch_norm=False)

Bases: Module

STPNN is a neural network with dense layers, which is used to calculate the spatial and temporal proximity of two nodes.

Parameters:

  • dense_layer – a list of dense layers of Neural Network

  • insize – input size of Neural Network

  • outsize – Output size of Neural Network

  • drop_out – drop out rate

  • activate_func – activate function

  • batch_norm – whether use batch normalization

forward(x)

Defines the computation performed at every call.

Should be overridden by all subclasses.

Note

Although the recipe for forward pass needs to be defined within this function, one should call the Module instance afterwards instead of this since the former takes care of running the registered hooks while the latter silently ignores them.

class gnnwr.networks.SWNN(dense_layer=None, insize=- 1, outsize=- 1, drop_out=0.2, activate_func=PReLU(num_parameters=1), batch_norm=True)

Bases: Module

SWNN is a simple neural network with dense layers, which is used to extract temporal and spatial features from the input data.

Parameters:

  • dense_layer – a list of dense layers of Neural Network

  • insize – input size of Neural Network

  • outsize – Output size of Neural Network

  • drop_out – drop out rate

  • activate_func – activate function

  • batch_norm – whether use batch normalization

forward(x)

Defines the computation performed at every call.

Should be overridden by all subclasses.

Note

Although the recipe for forward pass needs to be defined within this function, one should call the Module instance afterwards instead of this since the former takes care of running the registered hooks while the latter silently ignores them.

gnnwr.networks.default_dense_layer(insize, outsize)

generate default dense layers of Neural Network

Parameters:

  • insize – input size of Neural Network

  • outsize – Output size of Neural Network

Returns:

a list of dense layers

gnnwr.networks.weight_share(model, x, output_size=1)

weight_share is a function to calculate the output of neural network with weight sharing.

Parameters:

  • model – the neural network model

  • x – input data

  • output_size – output size of neural network

Returns:

output of neural network

class gnnwr.utils.DIAGNOSIS(weight, x_data, y_data, y_pred)

Bases: object

Diagnosis is the class to calculate the diagnoses of GNNWR/GTNNWR.

Parameters:

  • weight – output of the neural network

  • x_data – the independent variables

  • y_data – the dependent variables

  • y_pred – output of the GNNWR/GTNNWR

class gnnwr.utils.OLS(dataset, xName: list, yName: list)

Bases: object

OLS is the class to calculate the OLR weights of data.Get the weight by object.params.

Parameters:

  • dataset – Input data

  • xName – the independent variables’ column

  • yName – the dependent variable’s column
